In the great book that i finally finished reading (i was reading it very leisurely), Thoughts on Fire..., there is a very intriguing chapter about perfection. the chapter opens with a quote by W. Somerset Maugham, that states "Perfection is a trifle dull. It is not the least of life's ironies that this, which we all aim at, is better not quite achieved." With that said i would like to go on and quote the first part of the chapter, because this will make ppl realize that perfection will never be achieved.

"  The desire for perfection is one of the worst ideas anyone could have. It can be like a caustic acid that can destroy anything it comes into contact with. It can ruin your relationships, estrange you from your children and bring unhappiness to your work. Give up the idea of perfection my friends; it exists only in our minds. Some of the great philosophers, even people like Plato, were not immune to this disease. They imagined a realm of perfect forms that we should copy. Wrong, because once we have the idea there is such a thing as a perfect world, this world, the real world, ceases to shine. 
   
One problem with this approach is that it sets up an ideal of perfection that doesn't really exist. The whole concept of perfection bothers me. It's a goal of idea that can have a negative impact on a person's life if they're not careful. For instance, some of the more intelligent youngsters that i knew when i was in school thought that being smart meant they had to be perfect. To me, that is the worst way to look at the joys of school. I used to know a girl who was a straight-A student all throughout high school. When she got to college and she got a B-plus, it was a traumatic experience for her. Trying to do one's best is great; however, we are going too far when trying to be perfect makes us unhappy.
   
One of the worst ideas people could have is that they have to be perfect. Some people think that being perfect is their duty. They think that they should have a perfect marriage, perfect children, and perfect homes all the time. 
   
Well, we all know how things really work out in life. Our marriages aren't perfect, our houses aren't perfect and, heaven knows, our children aren't perfect. Then what happens to perfectionists? First, they get frustrated because they fail to reach their goals; next, they get angry; and then they get depressed. If they're not perfect and they think they should be, they see themselves as failures. They've set up their lives as a game where they're trapped. Once they define the alternatives as a perfection or failure, they can't win. If they  can't win, they can't be happy. The perfection game is a losing game. I've never known anybody who can beat the odds. 
   
That doesn't mean we can't be excellent in what we do. By excellence, I mean being the best we can be at any given time. A teacher should try to be the best teacher he can be; a butcher should try to be the best bucher in town; a painter should try to paint houses to the best of her ability. Martin Luther King once said to a street sweeper that he should 'sweep the streets like Michelangelo painted paintings.'" (132/133)

I just thought that this was a very well written, and extremely true, passage from the book. If you couldn't tell the book is about 50% philosophy and 50% firefighter stories. overall it's pretty "kickass"

ok, so im going to attempt to answer a few questions that keep coming up. these are questions that cannot be answered completely with a simple "yes" or "no" answer. so here goes.

the biggest question is "are u a 'real' firefighter now" (after completing my FF1 class). the answer is this.... when i joined the MFFD i was a member. the night i was sworn in at the february meeting i became a "member" of the fire dept. i took what was called a 'rookie course' and became a "rookie" at the firehouse. after the course i was able to ride the ambulance as a 4th, and even as an attendant.... i had also become exterior certified. then i took firefighter 1. this class is the first (and biggest) step to becoming an interior firefighter. after completing this class i only have to take a 1 day firefighter survival class and i will be interior. i also have to take CBT. this is required to be taken every year to remain in the position u hold (interior, exterior, ...). u go to different stations around the fire house and have to perform tasks ... if u complete all the tasks required for ur position then u keep ur status .. if not u have to do them over until u can complete them successfully.

now moving on to another big question, "why did u join the fire dept.?" ... this answer i cannot tell u in a few sentences or even paragraphs. i will tell u that doing over 120 hrs of community service there for HS was part of the reason. another huge part of the reason i joined was b/c my brother and my cousin are members. (i can honestly say that if my brother wasn't a member i probably wouldn't be a member either). however that isn't the biggest part of the reason. there is a very good book that explains this a little better. if u really want to know the reason to y i joined and y i do what i do read the book 'Thoughts on Fire, Life Lessons of a Volunteer Firefighter' it is written by Dr. Frank McCluskey. he is a member of MFFD, as well as a dean at mercy college and he has a PHD in philosophy. this book will give u a good understanding to y people join fire depts., what goes on there, and what firefighters go through. what makes this book better (at least to me) is that it was written about MFFD and relates to the dept and some of the older members too.

last night was the .... :::gasp::: ..... LAST NIGHT OF FIREFIGHTER 1 !!!!!!!
we had pretty bad results for our class though .... out of 12 ppl 5 failed, and 2 have to make up quizzes still. But i am one of 5 that passed and i also got a 100 on the final! neways afterwards we all decided to go to chili's for dinner. i rode there with Ari (a guy from class... the oldest person in the class at 35ish yrs old). he had his faster of the 2 lotus's that he owned (it's a lotus elise, his other is a lotus esprit). needless to say i thought i was gonna die b4 we got to chili's. he was making turns on stoneleigh ave. (and a few other roads on the way to chili's) at 120 mph. and he wasn't really even pushing the car! in the middle of stoneleigh ave he reassured me that i would not die b/c he had gone to a race car driver's school (and by the way he drove i wouldn't doubt it). now at 120 mph u would think that the car would be all over the road ... WRONG! the car didn't slide once the entire time, it was pretty much glued to the road. o and when i went to get into the car u literally had to climb to the ground to get in (i mean i've been in small sports cars b4 but this was the lowest). getting out was the exact opposite, u had to climb out. at chili's we all had a great time (we even told the ppl in back that it was charlie's b-day (the instructor), and they brought out a dessert thing for him. afterwards i rode back to the fire house with rob laprieno (sp?) in his ford escort. on the way there we hit 80 in his very crappy car, and hit a bump in one of the roads getting the car off the ground (not that much though). all in all i had an AMAZING last night of FF1 ... and now that it's over i can honestly say that i will miss the class (along with having a lot of free time now), and i hope that i will meet up with some of the ppl from the class, from other depts., at one point in my life. but that was definately THE BEST ending to a 3 month class (4/14/05 - 7/14/05) 2 days a week for "3" hrs a day (it ended up being MUCH LONGER)

ok so as you all know (at least u should) tonight is the first night of the fair at Mahopac's station 1. b3 the fair is always a parade (has been for like ever) ... something u probably don't know is that every year (usually minutes b4 stepoff) we get a big call in our district, and everything gets screwed up b/c some of the trucks have to leave (along with a lot of ppl) ... and of course we have to keep some there with ppl to march. well today was no exception.

at about 3:30ish a call came in for a car accident on secor rd. i was getting ready to leave when a second call came in. (i thought it was a second call for additional man power, however i was wrong)... the second set of tones was for a confirmed structure fire off of archer rd. so i grabbed my gear and went flying down secor rd (on my way to the firehouse .. to get on one of the trucks leaving for one of the accidents).
b4 i had gone 1/2 a mile secor i see a few volunteers going the opposite direction (going to the scene of the fire). a little farther down the road was the car accident with volunteers directing traffic. i found out they had everything under control, so i went straight to the fire house from there. on the corner of secor and 6N the attack truck past me going to the fire. i had noticed that other then the driver and "officer" of the truck there was only one other member on the truck and he had not yet been certified as interior. on the corner of 6N and the road by the fire house the tanker past me (idk what the name of that road is). so i go racing into the parking lot, and run to the rescue truck. when i got on i was surprised to see that there was only a driver and an "officer" on the truck (and the "officer" was only exterior certified). soon another exterior member would join me in the back of the rescue and off we went. (i had realized that we would have a problem with man power at the scene being as there were minimal interior members). 

we showed up to find a lot of ppl had driven straight to the scene and were extinguishing the fire (along with mutial aid from mahopac). we all helped out with whatever we could and eventually (after the fire was out) we were sent in for overhaul and salvage. we did what we could and went back to the fire house.

but the work was far from over. now at the fire house we had to get every truck back in service, as well as get some of the trucks ready for the parade. after all the work was over it was around 6:20 and ppl had started leaving for the parade. and to think the fire could've been MUCH MUCH worse. 

in the end we had successfully saved a house (escaping only minimal damage), and we dealt with the car accident ON TOP OF getting everything ready for the parade. had we gotten to the house a little later the entire house would've been on fire and everything would've been destroyed. 

this was my first structure fire and im glad it had a good end to it. i hope everyone that is going to the parade appreciates what a lot of members put into getting there as well as getting the trucks there. and i hope everyone attending the fair has a great time. that's all for now.......

ok i know kevin is goin to hate this, but for journal purposes i am goin to describe the call i went on yesterday in somewhat detail (i however will not release the names of the victims as i am not allowed to ... so either you know them and this story already or you don't). This was my first ambulance call since i joined the department (i've made other calls but this is the first i was able to make an ambulance call so i am making this entry). I will dedicate this entry to the three victims and the Mahopac Falls and Mahopac personal who responded...

I arrived at the Fire house at about 6:20 pm, for my Firefighter 1 course that started at 7 (i always get there early). After hanging out for a few minutes Brian Neary and myself decided to get chairs for the shed and set them up in the empty bay.(the third thurs of the month is the board of directors meeting so we have to have class downstairs). At about the exact moment that i took my first step the tones went off for a fire call (the beginning of the tones are different for fire and ambulance calls).

everyone went running to their turnout gear and proceded to get into it. then after the call was announced brian sacher puts his gear back throws his shoes back on and yells "we need a crew!" (as in an ambulance crew, b/c we just heard it was a car accident). so wo/ hesitating i run to the ambulance (as i know most ppl were in gear running to the rescue truck already. 

we pulled the ambulance out of the bay and awaited the rest of the crew (we only needed an EMT, but both laprienos were on their way) (that name is probably spelled wrong). the laprienos both show up and one gets on each ambulance ... along with bobby trace (an EMT) jumping on our ambulance. with this crew we leave. 

durring this time the paramedics were on scene along with mahopac's ambulance (mahopac may have come a little later im not totally sure).

On the way to the scene (on the corner of west lake drive and 6N) we see liz standing on the side of the road across the street from red mills. (shes a Lieutenant of one of the ambulances and most likely heard the call and ran across the street and waited for us to pick her up). we picked her up and continued to the scene. there was one person out of one of the cars laying on the ground (how she got there i have no idea) and the two drivers stayed in their cars ... one was already on oxygen, the other appeared fine. 

while the person on the grass laying down was put on a back board and collared and such i helped get the guy out of a white pickup that the front end was completely screwed up on (mostly the left side). he was collared, put on a back board and then onto the stretcher. he complained of his left arm hurting (possible fracture i suppose) he was put on mahopac's ambulance and off to the hospital they went. 

by this time the door to the black audi was extracated and they were starting to pull the girl out of the car and onto a backboard (she was collared and on oxygen still). i went with this victim onto the ambulance with the paramedics (she was in the worst condition out of the three and was being airlifted). we rushed to the school with the ambulance and assisted the helicopter crew getting her onto the helicopter and watched them take off. she complained of severe lower back pain and pain in her left leg (she could wiggle her toes... and i took the sign of pain as a good thing b/c im assuming that she isn't going to be paralysis). 

the person laying on the ground, at some point durring the trip to the HS, was taken to the hospital as well. 

from the looks of the scene one would guess that the white pickup was comming out of west lake turning right and the black audi going up 6N (towards the school). from this i incorrectly assumed that the pickup made a wide trun too fast into the other lane hitting the audi by the driver's side door. i later found out that the pickup was going down 6N (traveling straight and staying on 6N) while the audi was turning left out of west lake and was broad sided, both cars turning sideways to look like the scene we arrived at. in order for that to happen the pickup had to be speeding and was most likely still the cause of the accident. 

we returned to the fire house and took the course (we got there at 7:30 so we ended up staying late). there wasn't really anyone there at 7 b/c all the ppl in our dept in the course, were on the call. 

as for my emotions during this time ... they were unexpected and i will definately highlight most of them just for record purposes. i was looking forward to an easy night of haz mat when i left my house and arrived at the fire house. when the call came in it was unexpected and i (wanting to, but not wishing injury upon anyone ... just wanting to help when the time came) finally got to go on the ambulance. this had me anxious as well as nervious b/c i didn't know how bad the victim would be. (when i first jumped on the ambulance sacher said it was gonna be a bad call). that caused me to think "great.. my first ambulance call ... a bad one" when we got to the scene i was shocked b/c the drivers were both 16 yrs old, and i've seen them in school (i believe both are in junior yr). then the thought went through my mind that this could be me and that b4 they even knew what happened their cars were destroyed, spun around, and they were injured. i felt great that i was there helping .. but more bad that this happened and that it was possible to happen to anyone and there was no way to avoid it. i mean it's not like a fire call where a house burns down but everyone is alright ... this had worse results. i especially felt bad for the victims that i myself thought were innocent in this whole thing and should not have been hurt. However, you really wouldn't understand exactly how i felt if u weren't there (which u obviously weren't) b/c if u were there u would feel the same way. 

i would now just like to say that all the info that i supplied (concerning the victims future results) is not said to be completely accurate  b/c i only know how they were until they left the ambulances. this call will definately impact my life and hopefully who ever reads this will be changed for the better. and just so u know most of the time it is the other driver who is at fault and causes the accident .. but u are involved and have no control. 

I wish all the victims a complete recovery and hopefully they can return to their lives as normal when they recover. However i know that they will never forget this horrible time in their life and you shouldn't either. and i would also like to thank Mahopac's FD for mutual aid ... as well as Mahopac Falls FD for being there to help (as well as me being able to help through the FD)...

ok so this entry was suggested by kevin a while ago, and im finally getting around to it. i know it is gonna absolutely suck and not even come close to kevin's entry of the same topic, but that's ok. This is a list of 10 random people that have influenced my life (they are not in any order). they have not all been positive influences, but i guess u will figure that out when u read it.

Mike M. ... Mike (aka "Mr. Smiley" to melissa) is probably my best friend. He is in 9th grade right now. He lives and has lived down the street from me for literally ever. I've known him pretty much since he was born (only about 8 months after i was) and we've been friends since i can remember. He is the one person that i can without a doubt trust with ANYthing.

Mr. Gorey ... i don't think many people that read this will know him b/c he was my 5th grade teacher from Austin Road. My class was the last class to have him, as he retired right after. He was the first teacher i had that i considered the "best" teacher. He gave a lot of work at times, but there was lots of time for fun. Also i learned a lot of stuff that yr (on top of the useless required stuff, he taught a lot of interesting useful stuff) u really have to have had him to understand.

Kevin ... I met kevin in 7th grade. When i first met him i was told that he is this genius, and that he is the smartest kid in the grade (which is still true but the way i was presented with the information he was looked up to like a god). At first Kevin and i started off as average friends... and then he eventually told the entire grade that i liked meaghan molloy (that's a whole other story ... read the entry titled 7th grade for that one). Then somehow we became good friends again and he managed to screw up again by writing a letter to guidence saying i was gonna kill myself (that was bad). However even after all that kevin and i remain friends (despite the random arguments we get into sometimes ... but hopefully he doesn't take them seriously b/c i sure don't). 

Remie ... I met remie in 7th grade. He was and is one weird kid. He is constantly made fun of for his name (which is one name i would never name my kid) and seems to always be depressed about something. He was involved with the meaghan thing and many other things against me. Time after time i remained friends with him (even after everything he did to me). eventually he got mad at me for nothing .. so i decided that i didn't need his crap and wasn't gonna be his friend nemore. when he tried to be friends with me again i didn't allow it b/c i didn't need to be bothered with his crap nemore (he wasted all the sympathy i had for him). there is much more to this but again im not gettin into it now. Currently we are NOT friends.

Mickey ... I met mickey in 8th grade through erik lanza (also a cool kid but one that isn't mentioned in this ... as a lot of ppl aren't). Mickey and i became great friends and to this day are still good friends. His one weakness is his ability to not be mean to anyone. No matter what happens mickey will always be a nice person about it (especially when it comes to friends) ... kevin coined the term "too nice syndrome" for this (i believe that was what he called it). Overall mickey is an amazing person and i could probably write a book on him in the few years that i've known him, yes he is just THAT cool. 

Mr. Peterson ... I said b4 that Mr. Gorey was the first teacher that was the best teacher ... until 8th grade that is. Mr. Peterson was THE BEST teacher that i have ever had thus far. Mr. Peterson did NOT believe in busy work. If he gave work there was a reason for it. His tests were hard (not that i did bad on them, b/c i didn't, but they were hard) ... however the reason for this was to make the regents an absolute joke. How many teachers do u know that can stand up and say (during the moving up ceremony from 8th to 9th) that the avg regents grade for his students that yr was a 95. something???? not any that i can think of offhand. ok so i told kevin no more of these entries (but my life is boring other than this stuff) AND it's different this time. this wednesday we went to the carmel training center (aka the burn center or the tower) originally the drill was supposed to be ladders and mask confidence but they added a lil more to it. 

at about 7:10 we left the fire dept on the rescue and one ambulance (there was about 30 ppl and there definately wasn't enough room for them all between the 2 trucks. on the way there this kid (a rookie) jim fatone (was standing in the rescue as he was one of the ppl that didn't have a seat) and he almost fell but instead sat on another rookies helmet and cracked the sheild in half (if u know jim u know he lives up to his name of "FAT ONE") 

so when we got to the training center they told us to go to the meeting room (i guess that's what it was) and we soon found out that we had a very LARGE group of ppl (bout 27 not counting officers or senior members)... they told us there will be 4 stations; mask confidence, 35' ladder, roof ladder, and inital attack. so they gave us all numbers and split us up into 5 groups.

the first station my group did was the 35' ladder. (lettme just say this ladder is 35' long, has 3 leafs and weighs in excess of 200 lbs.) we placed the ladder up to the 3rd story of the tower and ppl climbed it with a pipe pole. once at the top u had to check for footing get off the ladder (onto the floor), then get back onto the ladder, do a "leg lock" (which is where u lock ur legs around the ladder, let go wit ur hands and lean back). after that u climb back down the ladder and ur part is pretty much over. between getting the ladder up, doin that part of the drill and putting the ladder back down .. i think my group did a good job. (just so u know all this was done in full turn out gear w/ scott packs)

the next station we did was the roof ladder station. this ladder was much much easier to maneuver (as it was much lighter and shorter) we placed the ladder on the second story (by a window simulation thing). one person would go up the ladder as the rescuer and some one would go up right behind him as a "balancer". the victim would be handed out the window by 2 other ppl already up there and the rescuer would carry him down the ladder. (it was more like sliding him down .. hard to explain) ... everyone had the chance to be the victim and the rescuer. (this was done with full turnout gear as well)

the next station we were assigned to was inital attack. this was based on a basement fire. so of course i was picked to be on the nosal. we went down a ramp, into a room (with furniture), then around a little bit, and eventually came to a set of stairs, went down the stairs "put out the fire" and went back. at the end the cheif handed everyone a piece of the hose wit the coupling and asked the ppl to find the way out (if u picked the wrong way to go based on the coupling, u were "dead" if u picked the right way to go then u can go back to the truck). o and did i mention this entire thing was done with our fire hoods on backwards, so we couldn't see NETHING (as well as the room being pitch black so that didn't help). we did it in full turnout gear on our hands and knees. and on side note, noone chose the wrong way to go based on the coupling.

now the last station was mask confidence. my group did not get to do it (as we were short on time and had to go back) but i will just describe it here neways. in full turn out gear, w/ scott pack and hood over ur scott mask (so u can't see nething). u basically had to go through an opstical course wo/seeing nething. there are parts where u have to take off the scott pack and slide it in front of u while u go under an 18" high wall. (in that part ur helmet also had to come off b/c it doesn't fit through). ur scott pack also has to come off a few other times when u go through a wall wit 16" beams. throughout the entire course u gotta follow a hose that goes through the whole thing.

after that we went back to the fire house, cleaned the 2 trucks that we used, washed the hoses off, and that was the end of the night. (in not too much detail)
overall the night was really fun (even though i didn't get much sleep) and im really looking forward to the live burn we are gonna have there in april sumtime
